Issues.Title: feat(model): add .eager modifier
Issues.Body:
Add an `.eager` modifier to v-model that ignore `composing` value on the input and eagerly modify the value while the user is still composing a value. #9299 #9777

Since the default keyboard on Android, GBoard, does composing by default, I think it makes sense to have a modifier to disable the composing behaviour while still benefitting from using v-model

Issues.Title: transition beforeEnter never called
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/7hypa902/2/](https://jsfiddle.net/7hypa902/2/)







### Steps to reproduce
1. create a component with root node as transition, with a beforeEnter hook
2. compile it with vue-loader, to make a es5 friendly single js file
3. mount it in a browser environment - the beforeEnter hook is never called

### What is expected?
consistent behavior regarding transition events

### What is actually happening?
the event isn't fired

---
It is worth noticing that the component and the transition works when using webpack dev server and a "standard" dev flow, but not when compiling component into a single file. I'd suggest it's related to either the style loader injection or maybe something about vue-loader but i'm not sure.

The fiddle consists of the failing built component, isolated and placed in a minimal Vue shell.

I've been trying to hack around, modifying the listener registration `"on: { beforeEnter: _vm.beforeEnter "` and tried to go further with breakpoint to know the cause, but i can't follow it properly. I've already read the other bug report mentioning "calculation on beforeEnter" but even when commenting the listener, it still happen.

Issues.Title: vue props 传入对象或数组的正确方式应该是怎么样的？
Issues.Body:
```
prop 是单向绑定的：当父组件的属性变化时，将传导给子组件，但是不会反过来。这是为了防止子组件无意修改了父组件的状态——这会让应用的数据流难以理解。
```

上面是文档中的描述，但是如果在props中传递的是对象或是数组，根据JavaScript的特性，传递过来的是引用类型，所以我在子组件中也是能够修改父组件的数据的。
为了避免干扰父组件数据，难道每次都将props数据转换成深拷贝的局部变量或计算属性吗？
如何优雅的方式解决这种双向数据？
为什么props传递过来的数据不使用深拷贝？
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "vue props 传入对象或数组的正确方式应该是怎么样的？" (#9809)

In webpack production mode, some modules may be concatenated by scope hoisting via ModuleConcatenationPlugin, so these modules' mapping information will be lost.

For example: modules info for `qux.js`, `quux.js` and `quuz.js` are lost

```js
{
  "modules": [
    {
      "chunks": [...],
      "identifier": "foo.js",
    },
    {
      "chunks": [...],
      "identifier": "bar.js"
    },
    {
      "chunks": [...],
      "identifier": "baz.js",
      "modules": [
        {
          "identifier": "qux.js"
        },
        {
          "identifier": "quux.js"
        }
        {
          "identifier": "quuz.js"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

This pr change is traversing the ConcatenatedModule and populate the modules info.

Issues.Title: Proposal: slotted attributes
Issues.Body: ### What problem does this feature solve? Often times, I have a situation where I have a reusable component that I've built, but I want to expose one of the child nodes as a "target" of sorts where attributes can be added to or modified. Now, I could add a property or event-listener on the parent specifically to be used by the child, but often times its difficult to think of the different attributes the end user of the component might want to modify, or the events they'd like to listen to on this target child. I COULD add a large set of optional properties, prefixed by some descriptor to indicate what sub-part of the component they will be applied to (e.g `$props = { bodyClass, footerClass, menuClass }, $listeners = { footerClicked, headerFieldChanged}`... etc), but this has a few drawbacks: - its inelegant - its very verbose - its utility is limited by my ability to think of all the attributes on a child target that I or someone using this component might want to modify or extend, and that doesn't even touch on if the consumer wanted to add a directive. And so, my proposal is that Vue add a new feature, which I admittedly couldn't think of a good name for, so I went with `slotted-attributes` for now. Mostly because I think the cleanest implementation would be an extension of slots. I realize this name has good deal baggage that could confuse users, though, so I'm not attached to this name or the slots approach inherently, mostly just the feature, in some form or fashion. ### What does the proposed API look like? I have a suspicion this will be seen as a convolution of the API, but to me, most intuitive way to implement this would simply be to add a `attrs` modifier to the `v-slot` directive. For example: _Template using the the slotted attributes_ ```html
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Proposal: slotted attributes" (#9796)

Issues.Title: Proxy issue between two vue apps when created with vue-cli3
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.6

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/srchulo/vue-cli3-proxy-error](https://github.com/srchulo/vue-cli3-proxy-error)







### Steps to reproduce
1. Go into public app and type "yarn serve".

2. Go into app/ and type "yarn serve"

3. Go to http://localhost:8080

4. Open the developer console.

5. Click "Go to App" link in the top right.

6. Observe the console (web socket connection closes before it is established, and failed requests show).

7. Make a change to app/, observe that hot reload will not occur.

### What is expected?
Websockets should successfully be proxied to the Vue app on port 8081 and hot reload for the app on 8081 should work.

### What is actually happening?
The websockets never connect, there are many failed requests, and hot reload does not work.

---

I did not have this issue when my project was on vue-cli2-- it was once I upgraded to vue-cli3 that I saw this issue.

These are some of the errors that I observe:

Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/GaryChu/pen/EJYRKz?editors=1011](https://codepen.io/GaryChu/pen/EJYRKz?editors=1011)

- bind

- \>\>\> bubbling
- \>\>\> capturing

or

It prints:

---

according to [W3C event model](https://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/#event-flow) and [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener):

> Events in the target phase will trigger all listeners on an element regardless of the useCapture parameter.

unbind of custom directives should remove all event listener, or trigger all event listener include both capture's and bubble's

Issues.Title: Expose a way to get route string from a router object.
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
I think it would be nice if there is a helper function that parse an object to an URL based on matched route from routers list. 

Currently, we have to use `<router-link>` and bind that object to `:to`, but what if I want to bind a `<a :href="">`?

```html
<a :href="`/video/${video.id}`?t=${video.t}`">
```
This is ok. However, sometimes, the route path changes (for example: `/videos` instead of `/video`), in that case we have to find all the `<a>` and replace with the new path, I don't think it's a good idea.

But if we use the route name instead of the path, it will work despite of changing route path.

### What does the proposed API look like?
```js
this.$router.parseURL({ name: 'Video', params: { id: 'funny-video' }, query: { t: 200 } })

// /video/funny-video?t=200
```

Issues.Title: Multiple guards on one route
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
My application contains routes that require multiple layers of validation to run before proceeding to them. Some of my routes must have an 'Organization' selected. If a user attempts to hit the route without having an organization selected, they are redirected to another route to set up an organization. All of my routes require that a user is authenticated, or else they are redirected to my auth server.

I understand that it is possible to nest each of my guards in one single guard; however, I have unique combinations of guards per route (not all routes have the same guards), which makes it difficult to express the requirements of a route without writing a guard to contain each guard the route requires (versus something easier and more expressive, such as an array).

In my opinion, this is clearly a responsibility of the framework to support this. I have heard the arguments that you can write one guard that contains each guard inside of it, but is that really a solution when we have multiple people asking for this feature? If many consumers of Vue require this feature, and they're all writing their own implementations to support this functionality, it should be absorbed into the framework.

The problem is common enough to justify given the strong support demonstrated by Issue #721

### What does the proposed API look like?
```
let router = new VueRouter({
    routes: [
        {
            path: '/dashboard',
            name: 'dashboard',
            component: ...,
            beforeEach: [guard1, guard2],    // Each guard is a function accepting (to, from, next)
        }
});
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Multiple guards on one route" (#2687)

Issues.Title: Page refresh after addRoutes method fails to load the new route
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/EvanBurbidge/vue-router-tester](https://github.com/EvanBurbidge/vue-router-tester)







### Steps to reproduce
- Clone the project
- Install dependencies
- Run the project
- Navigate to /testing
- reload the page
- then navigate to the about page
- navigate to the foo link
- reload the page

### What is expected?
When I reload the page the tester component is fetched for the /testing route. Or when I navigate to the foo component and reload the page I should see the same component load. 

### What is actually happening?
When we reload the page I expect the component assigned to that route to be present, however it does not load on page refresh, the router is setup within a parent component and on page refresh this data is lost. Looking at the router.options.routes I can see that it is not modified with a new route when we call the addRoutes method. When trying to store the configuration in localStorage / sessionStorage we lose the import part of the component.

---
While this method is handy for adding new routes to the router, you will never know when a user is going to reload their browser, if some data goes wrong or something like that, therefore we should probably ensure that this method allows us to easily add new routes that will persist through a page refresh, if I am 2/ 3 child levels deep into a set of components then when I refresh I should see those components not a blank screen.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Memory leak happening while using registerModule/unregisterModule.
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.1.0

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/mrj8spu0/](https://jsfiddle.net/mrj8spu0/)







### Steps to reproduce

1. Open the JSFiddle link mentioned as part of this issue.
2. Check and record the heap memory in the browser on initial stage.
3. Click on the "Register" button to dynamically register Module B 100 times
4. Now we will see an increase in heap memory on account of registering module 100 times.
5. Click on "Un-Register" button to dynamically un-register Module B 100 times
6. Check the heap memory again, at this point will see an jump in memory usage on account of un-registering 100 module. 

### What is expected?
Heap memory generated on step 3 & 5 must be cleared after step 6. (Final stage)

### What is actually happening?
Heap memory of the browser is not getting cleared.

---
We are observing memory leak of Store._vm while using registerModule/unregisterModule extensively.
On heap profiling we found that the oldVm instance is not getting garbage collected.

Probable Solution:
De-reference the oldVm instance on the same function scope where its getting instantiated (i.e. resetStoreVM() )

The above can be achieved by adding following code inside resetStoreVM function.

oldVm.$destroy(); 
oldVm = null; // This is the missing code

Attached google chrome (V 72.0.3626.96) heap snapshot and file.

### What is expected?
The tests should run fine and circular imports should work. They *DO* work in the browser just not in Mocha testing environment.

Error as follows:

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'getters' of undefined
```

Issues.Title: watch instance method behavior is inconsistent between Vue and Vuex
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.1.0

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/ianwalter/vuex-issue](https://github.com/ianwalter/vuex-issue)

### Steps to reproduce
1. Register a watcher in a component with a callback function that prints the new data value and old data value
2. Register a watcher on a store instance with a callback function that prints the new data value and old data value

### What is expected?
That when both watchers are triggered, both of them print the new data value and the old data value.

### What is actually happening?
The component watcher prints the new data value and old data value, while the store watcher only prints the new data value (state) and an empty object (getters, if you haven't defined any). 

---
Before reading the Vuex documentation more closely, I assumed that this method behaved in the same way as it does in a component. Returning getters to the store watcher callback seems to me like returning computed in the component watcher callback. I think the old state data is more valuable too, especially since it could provide the initial state as the old data, something you can't get in an alternative way (like subscribing to mutations which only gives you the new state as well).

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "watch instance method behavior is inconsistent between Vue and Vuex" (#1504)

Issues.Title: DOCUMENTATION REQUEST: how to publish vuex module on npm. how to publish sfc component library and vuex module on npm
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Vuex modules, in theory, are divorced of their vue components which access them. One could take the module, register it and (re)make components to utilize the vuex module as desired. However, in (perhaps poor) practice, vuex modules and vue components are often made concurrently; namely, the components serve as the api to the store and it is expected that inclusion of the vue components come _with_ the vuex module.

However turning a vuex module and library of sfcs into reusable chunks does not seem to be straight forward.

The expected behavior would be using the vue-cli to create a new project with a vuex store.
the store would be moved to its own directory:

```
src/
-- store/
---- modules/
------ moduleA/
-------- actions.js
-------- state.js
-------- mutations.js
-------- getters.js
-------- store.js 
...
```

All components under `src/components` (or nested directories) would be exposed so users could import each constitute component
All modules under `src/store/modules` would be exposed so users could just import the module if desired 


### What does the proposed API look like?
```
# install library
npm install vuex-vue-sfc-library

# inside app.vue or some other component
// import the vuex modules and components that access the modules 
import {moduleA, nestedComponentB, conglomerateComponentA} from 'vuex-vue-sfc-library

export default {
    components: {
        nestedComponentB, conglomerateComponentA
    },
    created() {
        this.$store.registerModule('moduleA', moduleA)
    }

}
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "DOCUMENTATION REQUEST: how to publish vuex module on npm. how to publish sfc component library and vuex module on npm" (#1502)

Issues.Title: Confusing namespaced api
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
The most confusing thing when using namespaced vuex is inconsistant api with state and getters.

Example:
to access state 
`this.$store.state.user.name`

to access getter
`this.$store.getters['user/fullName']`

This is so confusing for me and my coworkers. Is there reason to have this inconsistency?



Problem occurs when you try to watch getters
example:
```
watch: {
  '$store.state.user.name': {
    handler(name) {
      console.log(name)
    },
  },
  '$store.getters[user/fullName]': { // not working
    handler(fullName) {
      console.log(fullName)
    },
  },
}
```
Current solution Is to use mapGetters() helper for getters only. Why? because of weird api.
Please note that we try to avoid mapGetters, mapState helpers... due to explicitly in large app

### What does the proposed API look like?
Add api for getters same as is for state.

Example:
`$store.gettters.user.fullName`

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Confusing namespaced api" (#1500)
